DOCNAME: CASE OF MATUSHEVSKYY AND MATUSHEVSKA v. UKRAINE
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 2 (substantive aspect);Violation of Art. 2 (procedural aspect);Violation of Art. 3
JUDGES: Angelika Nußberger;Dean Spielmann;Elisabet Fura;Ganna Yudkivska;Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants’ DATE son , PERSON ( “ GPE ” ) , was placed in ORG no . CARDINAL ( “ the GPE ” ) following his arrest on suspicion of a drug - related offence .
CARDINAL . On DATE was examined by a medical commission which found him to be in good health .
CARDINAL . On DATE a drug specialist found him to be in unstable remission from drug addiction .
CARDINAL . On DATE GPE was placed in cell no . CARDINAL , which was shared by CARDINAL inmates . It was his sixth transfer to a different cell in the GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME , the inmates of cell no . LOC knocked on the door and informed the prison guard that GPE had fallen from the upper bed and had fainted . TIME , a medical attendant and the on - duty doctor arrived . According to an entry made by them in GPE ’s medical record , they administered the following injections to him : cordiamin , cortisol , mezaton , caffeine and atropine . He was then transported to the medical unit , still alive . At CARDINAL p.m. an ambulance , for which the prison administration had called , arrived ; and at CARDINAL TIME was pronounced dead . According to the medical certificate written by the PERSON administration and the doctors recording GPE ’s death , a closed craniocerebral injury was indicated as the preliminary cause of death .

CARDINAL . On DATE inmates , as well as the personnel involved , gave written statements concerning the matter to the GPE ’s governor . The detainees explained that there had been no incidents in the cell , that GPE had accidentally fallen from his bed and that they had unsuccessfully tried to bring him back to consciousness by putting a wet towel on his forehead . According to them , they had promptly called for a doctor , who , in turn , had arrived without delay . The inmates also submitted that TIME before his death ORG had complained of headache . CARDINAL of the detainees noted that GPE had occasionally mentioned that he suffered chest pains .
CARDINAL . In TIME on the same date , CARDINAL DATE , the PERSON administration examined the scene and informed the GPE police and ORG ( “ the LOC ” ) of GPE ’s death .
CARDINAL . On DATE at TIME , the PERSON administration sent a telegram to the applicants informing them that their son had died and that they could collect his body from the GPE morgue .

CARDINAL . According to the applicants , at TIME on CARDINAL DATE , before the telegram had reached them ( on DATE ) , they received an anonymous phone call from a person who had introduced himself as a detainee at the GPE . He had allegedly stated that GPE had been killed by GPE officers .

CARDINAL . The applicants immediately got in contact with the local morgue , which confirmed that GPE ’s body was there . However , according to the applicants , its staff refused to show them his body .
CARDINAL . The first applicant also informed the LAW of the allegations received in the anonymous phone call and sought the opening of a criminal investigation into the matter .
CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE , ORG found that there was no indication of a homicide and terminated the investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE , from TIME , the first applicant waited outside the morgue while an autopsy of GPE ’s body was going on . He saw some people there ( whom he later found out were from the GPE ) and allegedly heard CARDINAL of them saying on the phone : “ Everything is fine , the haematomas have been removed and the bruises behind the ears have been retouched . There is something there with his heart and lungs . ” The applicant had the impression that the conversation had been about his son .

CARDINAL . After the autopsy was completed , the first applicant was allowed to collect GPE ’s body . According to him , he discovered the following injuries on it : GPE ’s chest , shoulders , arms and legs , as well as his groin area , were covered with bruises , his fingertips were bluish in colour , the phalanx bone of the little finger on his left hand was broken , his face was swollen and his nasal bridge was deformed , the hair on his temples was missing as if it had been torn out , and there were bloodstains on his earlobes . The applicant asked the doctor about the injuries and was told that they were the signs of post - mortem lividity .
CARDINAL . The morgue issued a death certificate to the first applicant indicating that the cause of death had “ not been preliminarily clarified ” .

CARDINAL . Later on DATE , the applicants discovered in their mailbox a letter from an anonymous “ detainee ” , according to which GPE had been beaten up by one of the inmates , T. , on police instructions with a view to extracting a confession from him , and had died of the injuries he had sustained . It was noted in the letter that the PERSON administration was intimidating the witnesses in order to conceal the real cause of death . However , the witnesses would give truthful testimonies if questioned by the prosecutor in absence of GPE staff .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the first applicant again complained to the ORG that his son had been killed in the GPE . On an unspecified date shortly thereafter the prosecutor questioned him as to what made him think that GPE ’s death had been a violent one . The first applicant referred to the information received from the anonymous phone call and letter . He also noted that his son had not made any complaints about his health . Furthermore , on DATE , the last time that the second applicant had passed over a food parcel for GPE , she had enquired with the GPE medical staff whether he needed any medicine but had been told that he did not require any .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE , the assistant to the GPE governor , who had been on duty when GPE had died , gave a written statement to the ORG , according to which : there had been no incidents in cell no . CARDINAL on CARDINAL May ; no coercive measures had been applied to any detainees ; and he had not seen any injuries on GPE ’s body . The senior security officer on duty made a similar statement .

CARDINAL . On DATE T. and CARDINAL other inmates repeated their previous account of the events ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) to the LOC , without specifying what aid they had provided to GPE before the medical attendant ’s arrival , which had been TIME after GPE ’s fall . The inmates from the neighbouring cells , nos . CARDINAL and CARDINAL , stated that they had not heard any noise from cell no . CARDINAL on DATE . The prosecutor also questioned detainee PERSON , with whom GPE had been sharing cell no . CARDINAL before his transfer to no . CARDINAL . , and who , according to the applicants , might have had additional information about the circumstances of his death . PERSON submitted that GPE had not wanted to encounter T. and had therefore been unwilling to be transferred to cell no . CARDINAL . ORG had allegedly warned the administration about a possible conflict between GPE and GPE , as , according to him , they had been “ opposites in the criminal world ” .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the prosecutor questioned the GPE governor as regards , in particular , the reasons for GPE ’s frequent transfers from one cell to another . The governor stated that ORG had had a negative influence on other detainees , without giving further details . He submitted that GPE had neither opposed his transfer to cell no . CARDINAL nor had he later asked to be transferred to another cell . T. and GPE had not shared cells before . The governor also contended that he had not received any information about conflicts between them or about any wrongdoing on the part of T. According to him , the atmosphere in cell no . CARDINAL had been calm .

CARDINAL . On DATE T. stated that he had known GPE since DATE because they had lived in the same town . According to him , they had been neither friends nor enemies , rather just acquaintances . He also supplemented his earlier statements to the effect that the inmates had tried to bring GPE back to consciousness by pouring water on him and by rubbing his hands , feet and ears .
CARDINAL . On DATE a toxicologist of ORG issued a report , according to which no alcohol had been discovered in GPE ’s blood .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE another forensic medical report was issued by a histologist following an examination of GPE ’s body tissues . It concluded that the deceased had been suffering from : swelling of the lungs and haemorrhaging , focal serous bronchopneumonia , chronic leptomeningitis , fatty liver disease , chronic persistent hepatitis , signs of chronic nephritis , and atheromatosis of the aorta .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to open a criminal case regarding the death of GPE for want of indication of a crime .
CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE Deputy Prosecutor quashed the aforementioned decision as having been delivered prematurely .

CARDINAL . On DATE the forensic medical expert who had performed the autopsy gave a written statement to the ORG . He stated that there had been bruises and sores on GPE ’s face , both earlobes , and on the inner parts of both thighs , while no bone fractures or craniocerebral injuries had been discovered . The expert expressed the view that a possible cause of GPE ’s death could have been a heart or lung condition .

CARDINAL . On the same date detainee ORG additionally explained that he had wanted to stay in the same cell as GPE because the latter had often received food parcels and had shared them with his cellmates .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG refused to institute criminal proceedings against the GPE staff in respect of GPE ’s death for a lack of corpus delicti in their actions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Frankivskyy ORG in GPE terminated the pending criminal proceedings against GPE given that he had died . It also issued a separate ruling in which it noted that the circumstances of GPE ’s death warranted a criminal investigation ( it had been informed by the PERSON administration that GPE had died because of a closed head injury ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG quashed the decision of DATE and resumed the investigation . In particular , it noted that it was still necessary to question the ambulance doctors , to analyse the anonymous letter received by the applicants with a view to establishing its author , to question T. as to whether he had suffered any injuries , and to take steps to find out who had telephoned the applicants on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants complained to the ORG that the cause of their son ’s death had never been officially established . They pointed out that the accounts of the GPE governor in that regard lacked consistency . Thus , according to them , he had explained that GPE had died because he “ had fallen from his bed ” , subsequently because he “ had fallen ill ” , and , lastly , because he “ had fallen down in the shower ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE a forensic medical report was issued , according to which a chemical examination had discovered the presence of an organic substance possibly belonging to a group of amphetamines ( psychostimulant drugs ) in GPE ’s body . A precise identification of the substance was impossible . At the same time , it was noted in the report that the examination had not revealed any traces of caffeine or atropine , amongst other substances .

CARDINAL . On DATE another forensic medical examination ( started on CARDINAL May ) was completed . It found the following injuries on GPE ’s body : CARDINAL sores , one on each side of the nose ; CARDINAL sores under the left eyebrow ; a brownish - red sore on the lower part of the right earlobe and a bluish - violet bruise on its upper part ; a bluish - violet bruise of QUANTITY behind the left earlobe and a similar bruise measuring QUANTITY behind the right earlobe ; a triangle - shaped sore on the neck behind the right ear ; a bluish - violet bruise of CARDINAL x CARDINAL cm on the inner side of the right thigh and a similar bruise of CARDINAL x QUANTITY on the inner part of the left thigh ; as well an area of QUANTITY on the front part of the left thigh which was bruised all over . The examination of GPE ’s internal organs revealed a CARDINAL x QUANTITY long and QUANTITY deep area of haemorrhaging in the right temple and a QUANTITY long and QUANTITY deep area of haemorrhaging in the left temple . The expert concluded that GPE had sustained the aforementioned injuries while still alive . He classified them as insignificant and having no relation to his death . No bone fractures were discovered . The examination report indicated cardiomyopathy , presumably caused by drug addiction , as the cause of GPE ’s death . It noted that GPE had been intoxicated by a psychostimulant substance belonging to the amphetamine group which had triggered a heart attack and death . Furthermore , it discovered features of the following conditions : focal serous bronchopneumonia and chronic leptomeningitis , fatty degeneration of the liver , chronic hepatitis and nephritis , atherosclerotic heart disease , thyroid hyperplasia and cardiomegaly . They were also found to have contributed to GPE ’s death .
CARDINAL . On DATE T. was examined by a forensic medical expert , who did not discover that he had suffered any injuries .

CARDINAL . By a letter of DATE , the GPE governor informed the ORG that an internal investigation had not revealed any drug trafficking in the GPE . He noted that the psychostimulant substance discovered in GPE ’s body might have been passed to him from the outside with his food parcel , given that he had not shared his food parcels with anybody .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG questioned the ambulance doctor who had pronounced GPE dead . He submitted that he had not seen any injuries on GPE , but only traces of bleeding from the nose and the left ear . He explained that he had given the “ closed craniocerebral injury ” diagnosis on the basis of the initial visual inspection , without giving further details .

CARDINAL . On DATE decided that the investigation had not revealed anything criminal in the actions of the GPE staff or GPE ’s cellmates . It therefore refused to institute criminal proceedings against them .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor of ORG quashed the aforementioned decision as premature and ordered further investigation , the aim of which was to clarify , in particular , how the injuries had been inflicted on GPE and how the drugs could have appeared inside the GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE informed the applicants of the developments in the investigation and invited them to study the case file if they wished to do so .

CARDINAL . On DATE inmates of cell no . CARDINAL gave further statements regarding the events of DATE . They noted that on DATE GPE had been exercising , after which the inmates had been taken to the shower area . Upon their return to the cell , GPE had complained about having a headache . They also stated that they had massaged and rubbed PERSON and had slapped him in the face after his fall to bring him to his senses .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered another decision refusing to open a criminal case against the PERSON administration or GPE ’s cellmates for a lack of corpus delicti in their actions . At the same time , the investigation into the death of GPE continued , without being targeted against any particular person .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ordered another forensic medical examination , this time by a commission of experts , with a view to finding answers to the following questions :
- when GPE had died and what the cause had been ;
- whether he had sustained any injuries and , if so , what their nature and origin were ;
- whether those injuries could have originated from being hit with blunt objects ( such as fists , feet , a stick , etc . ) , and , if so , what those objects had been ;
- whether his injuries could have originated from first aid provided to him ( rubbing of his ears , eyes , eyebrows and hands ) and , if so , which of the injuries were caused in such a manner ;
- whether there was a causal link between GPE ’s injuries and his death ;
- whether ORG had been suffering from any diseases or handicaps and , if so , whether those had had a causal link with his death ; and
- whether ORG had consumed any alcohol or drugs shortly before his death , and , if so , what their impact had been .

CARDINAL . On DATE a microscopic examination of GPE ’s internal organs revealed : subarachnoid haemorrhage in the pia mater surrounding the brain ( it was impossible to localise the bleeding with additional precision ) ; punctuate cerebral haemorrhage ; and renal haemorrhage .

DATE . On DATE the forensic medical commission of CARDINAL experts delivered its report . It confirmed that GPE had died of a heart attack at TIME on CARDINAL DATE . His injuries were estimated as light , with the exception of the subarachnoid haemorrhaging , which was of medium gravity . The haemorrhaging had commenced shortly before death and had originated from the repeated “ hitting and shaking ” action of blunt objects against the body . It could not be excluded that those objects had been fists , feet or other objects impossible to define . Given that the injuries were to different parts of the body , they could not all have been inflicted at the same time . Some of them – such as the sores on the nose and under the right eyebrow – could have originated from falling against a blunt object . The injuries could not be characterised as having resulted from first - aid efforts . No direct connection was established between ORG ’s injuries and his death . The experts also concluded that , prior to his death , GPE had suffered from a number of diseases – of the lungs , heart , kidneys and liver – which had been aggravated by a heart attack and had caused his death . They also confirmed that a psychostimulant substance had been found in his body , without commenting on how it was related to his death .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor of ORG quashed the decision of DATE as lacking a proper basis and ordered further investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG additionally questioned the toxicologist who had issued the report of CARDINAL June ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The expert specified that the drug discovered in GPE ’s body was not contained in any of the medications given to him by the doctors before his death . It could have stayed in the body for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor repeatedly inspected cell no . CARDINAL , together with a forensic medical expert ( a member of the commission authoring the report of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) ) and in the presence of CARDINAL of the detainees and CARDINAL attested witnesses . A detailed inventory was produced containing details of all the beds and furniture items and measurements of the distances between them .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG questioned the expert who had participated in the inspection of the cell on DATE ( see paragraphs DATE and CARDINAL above ) . Referring to the inspection of the scene , the expert stated that GPE could have hit himself against the table while falling from the upper bed , then against the bench next to the table , and , finally , against the floor . Most of his bruises and sores , as well as the cerebral haemorrhaging , could have resulted from such a fall . As to the bruises behind both ears , they could have resulted from the intensive rubbing which the inmates had resorted to , having no knowledge as to how first aid should be provided . Lastly , the expert noted that the subarachnoid haemorrhaging could be assessed as being of both light and medium gravity , as the major criterion for the categorisation of such an injury was the effect of time , which was not applicable to the circumstances under examination .

CARDINAL . On DATE another forensic medical expert participating in the commission which had issued the report of DATE was questioned by the prosecutor . She noted that the internal bleeding could have resulted from a generalised trauma to the dead body . It could have occurred owing either to blows or to falling against a hard surface .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG again refused to institute criminal proceedings against the PERSON administration or the detainees for a lack of corpus delicti in their actions . On the same date it informed the applicants of that decision and explained to them that they had the right to study the case file at the ORG ’s premises .
CARDINAL . On DATE the lawyer representing the applicants asked the ORG for a copy of the decision of CARDINAL DATE . On DATE the ORG granted that request .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor of ORG quashed the decision of CARDINAL DATE as based on an incomplete investigation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ordered a complex forensic medical examination with a view to finding answers to the same questions as posed on DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . The investigator noted , in particular , that there had been injuries on GPE ’s body and that initially a closed craniocerebral trauma had been given as a possible cause of his death . It remained , however , to be established whether GPE had in fact sustained the aforementioned injury and what the cause of his death had been .
CARDINAL . There is no information on the progress or outcome of the investigation .

CARDINAL . The applicants submitted to the Court CARDINAL colour photos of the dead body of their son , dressed and placed in a coffin . The only visible parts of his body are his face and hands . The bridge of his nose appears to be swollen . There are sores on the upper part of the bridge of his nose and below both eyebrows , and a bruise below his left brow . Both earlobes are covered with what appears to be bloodstains and bruises . There are also bruises and patches of missing hair on both temples . His fingertips and nails are bluish in colour .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW and LAW can be found in the judgment of PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § § DATE , DATE .
